learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate specialised, advanced and integrated knowledge of intercultural communication theories and skills.
Analyse critically the key role that communication plays in developing intercultural relations and in managing conflicts.
Evaluate how media and culture intersect to influence attitudes, perceptions and public opinions as well as cultural change.
Transmit knowledge and skills to specialist and non-specialist audiences.
Communicate effectively and appropriately with individuals, groups, and communities in diverse local, national and cultural contexts.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 (Reflective Essay) requires you to reflect on your own culture as an "insider". Your cultural group can be defined at a national level (e.g., Korean, Australian, or German) or at a subculture level (e.g., religious groups). In your reflective essay, you should first state your cultural identification, position yourself as a member of the cultural group you identify with, be it national or a subcultural group. Then you explain how your cultural identification conveys a sense of identity to you; what beliefs, values, practices, traditions and so forth are considered important and why they are important to you and your cultural group. You may include examples of products or practices of your culture but your reflective essay should go beyond simply introducing or describing what the cultural products (e.g., a type of traditional food) or practices (e.g., eating certain traditional food on a special occasion) are. You should explain the cultural meanings of those products or practices and what they tell us about the cultural beliefs and values important to your cultural group and how those beliefs and values influence your thinking (attitude), doing (behaviour) and being (identity). Reflecting on your own culture will help you to appreciate differences as well as similarities between cultures, which prepares you for Assessment 3. You need to apply at least one theoretical concept or a theory learned in the course in relation to culture, identity, and communication. Define all theoretical concepts you choose to use in your reflective essay to demonstrate your knowledge of the concepts and your ability to apply them. You may cite academic and non-academic references for your reflective essay. Do not cite Wikipedia as academic references for your essay. Include all references cited within your essay in the references list at the end. APA 7th edition referencing style is required. The UQ Library website has APA 7th edition referencing style guide. The word limit (1500) for this assessment is suggestive. No penalties will apply based on the sole reason that your assessment is over/under the suggested word limit. Further information on this assessment will be provided in class sessions and on Blackboard.

Include the following sections in your reflective essay:

  1. Title of your reflective essay.
  2. Brief description of the cultural group(s) with which you identify.
  3. The theoretical concept(s) and/or theories you choose to frame the discussion of your culture.
  4. Your reflection on how your culture shapes your attitude and behaviour.
  5. References list: All references cited within the essay should be included in the references list.


Note:

  1. This assessment should be submitted via Turnitin. Submission to the course coordinator or your tutor as email attachment will NOT be accepted.
  2. You are not required to include pictures in your reflective essay. However, if you choose to include pictures, please limit your pictures to maximum 2. You might experience problems submitting your assessment via Turnitin if your file size is too large.
  3. Your assessment is evaluated according to the marking criteria in this course, NOT evaluated with reference to the achievement of other students or your performance in other courses.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 2 consists of 5 in-class tests to be conducted in person during tutorial sessions over 5 weeks, starting in Week 4 and ending in Week 9 (inclusive). No in-class test is scheduled in Week 6 because Friday of Week 6 is a public holiday. Each in-class test weighs 6 marks. The duration of each test is about 30 minutes. Electronic devices, readings, and written notes are not permitted during the test. Tutors will provide hard copies of test worksheets to students in their tutorial session of the week, and students submit their completed test worksheet to their tutor at the end of the test time in the tutorial session.

In--class tests are in the format of short-answer questions. The question(s) of each test are based on the learning materials of a specific week including lecture notes and power points, tutorial notes and power points, and required readings that are available on Blackboard. More details of in-class tests will be provided in class sessions and on Blackboard course site.

Note:

  1. Each completed in-class test worksheet is to be submitted in the tutorial session in which the test is conducted. Submission of a completed in-class test worksheet to the course coordinator or tutor as email attachment will NOT be accepted.
  2. Your assessment is evaluated according to the marking criteria specified in this course, NOT evaluated with reference to the achievement of other students or your performance in other courses.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3 (Intercultural Experience Report) requires you to report on your experience of communicating with people from another culture as an "outsider". To accomplish this assessment task, you need to choose a culture or subculture other than your own, i.e. you are an "outsider" to this culture. You then need to search for academic and non-academic sources to learn about this culture and cultural group. Based on your research, you identify some aspects of the culture (e.g., certain cultural practices, traditions, values, beliefs, etc.) that you want to learn more about and provide a justification for why you choose to learn more about them. For the interaction part, locate about three persons from the cultural group you have chosen through personal, social, or academic networks (e.g., friends, colleagues, classmates, or professional associations of which you are a member, etc.). Interview them via a suitable medium (in person or online) to learn about their views regarding those aspects of the culture you are interested in learning more about. In other words, you learn about the culture you have chosen to study through interacting with people who are insiders of that culture. Provide your interview questions and summarise your main findings from interviews. Identify one or a set of potential intercultural problems that might arise in communication between members of the cultural group under study and members of your own culture (e.g., stereotypes, different beliefs and values, communication styles, etc.). Apply at least one theory to analyse the identified intercultural problem(s) and provide specific possible solutions, not just general statements. In the reflection part of your intercultural experience report, discuss your learning from this intercultural communication experience. You may cite academic and non-academic references for your report. Do not cite Wikipedia as academic references for your essay. Include all references cited within your report in the references list at the end. APA 7th edition referencing style is required. The UQ Library website has APA 7th edition referencing style guide. The word limit (2000) for this assessment is suggestive. No penalties will apply based on the sole reason that your assessment is over/under the word limit. Further information on this assessment will be provided in class sessions and on Blackboard.

Include the following sections in your report:

  1. Title of your intercultural report.
  2. Introduction: State your own cultural identity in the Introduction and the culture you have chosen to study as well as provide a justification for your choice of the culture to study as an outsider.
  3. Description of the culture under study: Provide a brief description of the specific aspects of culture you plan to focus on. 
  4. Intercultural interaction: Construct 3 to 5 interview questions you plan to ask to the members of the cultural group you have chosen to study and provide the interview questions in your assignment. Describe the characteristics of the persons you have chosen to interview and explain why you believe they are in the best position to answer your questions. Then provide a summary of your main findings from your interviews. There is no need to include the real names of the persons you have interviewed.
  5. Problem statement and application of theories: Identify one or a set of potential intercultural problems that might arise in communication between people from the cultural group under study and people from your own cultural group; analyse the problem(s) and provide specific possible solutions by drawing on theories and concepts learned in the course and the relevant literature you have searched.
  6. Reflection: Reflect on your experience of interacting with people from a cultural group different from your own and discuss what you have learned from this intercultural communication experience.
  7. References list: All references cited within the report should be included in the references list. APA 7th edition referencing style is required. The UQ Library website has APA 7th edition referencing style guide.


Note:

  1. This assessment should be submitted via Turnitin. Submission to the course coordinator or tutor as email attachment will NOT be accepted.
  2. You are not required to include pictures in your report. However, if you choose to include pictures, please limit your pictures to maximum 2. You might experience problems submitting your assessment via Turnitin if your file size is too large.
  3. Your assessment is evaluated according to the marking criteria in this course, NOT evaluated with reference to the achievement of other students or your performance in other courses.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

Week 1 Lecture: Introduction to the Course

This first lecture provides an overview of the course structure, learning activities, assessments, requirements, and other course related information.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 Lecture: Introduction to the Course This first lecture provides an overview of the course structure, learning activities, assessments, requirements, and other course related information.

Week 1 Tutorial: No tutorial

Tutorials commence in Week 2.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 Tutorial: No tutorial Tutorials commence in Week 2.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 Lecture: Culture and People

This lecture discusses dynamics of culture and explains how culture influences our thinking, doing and being.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Lecture: Culture and People This lecture discusses dynamics of culture and explains how culture influences our thinking, doing and being.

learning_activities.topic:

This tutorial discusses applications of theories to study and analyse culture.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Tutorial: Culture and behaviour This tutorial discusses applications of theories to study and analyse culture.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3 Lecture: Communication and Culture

This lecture explores models of communication and various ways in which communication reflects culture.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 Lecture: Communication and Culture This lecture explores models of communication and various ways in which communication reflects culture.

learning_activities.topic:

This tutorial discusses the influence of culture on how we view ourselves and others who are from our cultural group or who are not from our cultural group.

learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4 Tutorial: Perception and Culture This tutorial discusses the influence of culture on how we view ourselves and others who are from our cultural group or who are not from our cultural group.
